Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2012 12:41PM sweetbean wrote: I have a "variant of undetermined significance."  Here is my layman's take on genetic variations.  Think of the gene as a sentence - "I saw a bird."   Now think of the variant as a letter.  Spell the word "bird" as "berd" and the sentence is different, but the structure is maintained.  Everybody knows you saw a bird.   Now spell "saw" as "law."  Now the sentence is "I law a bird."  The structure of the sentence is no longer maintained.  So changes can exist in genes that don't change their expression.  However, some genetic mutations definitely change the expression of the gene, causing it to misfire in one direction or another.  When they have enough women and men with a genetic variation that have a specific type of cancer, then they can investigate what that variation might be doing to the expression of that gene.

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2012 02:15PM sweetbean wrote: Yes, genetic mutations can be spontaneous, but it is not that common.  However, everything has to start somewhere.  I wouldn't worry too much about your variant, though.  We have tons of variants - most don't do diddly squat.  The fact that you have no family history is significant. I'd be more reassured by that than worried by the variant.  Did you harvest your eggs?   Has your period come back?  There are fertility specialists that specialize in cancer survivors.

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2011 07:45PM sweetbean wrote: I follow a mostly vegan diet and feel amazing.  I believe that my diet and lifestyle really have helped me avoid a lot of side effects.  I believe that the junk in processed foods, sugar, alcohol, makes it harder for your body to process the medicines, so they stick around in your system longer.  I also haven't gained any weight - in fact, I have lost about ten pounds since being diagnosed a year ago. That being said, I don't believe that a vegan diet will cure your cousin's cancer.  I'm really sorry for your anguish- this must be incredibly difficult to watch.  It's really too bad that she won't even take surgery.  :(

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2012 05:04PM sweetbean wrote: I had a lymph node removal procedure called Reverse Arm Mapping - it is when they inject a dye into your arm about 5 minutes before the removal of the lymph nodes.  The dye has just enough time to travel to the arm lymph nodes, but not the breast lymph nodes.  So when the surgeon opens you up, he doesn't take the lymph nodes with the dye color, because they are not associated with the breast.  If you had a ton of lymph node involvement, then you would need to have them all removed, but it doesn't sound like that this the case here.  This procedure is supposed to help prevent lymphedema.  I had this procedure and they still removed 15 lymph nodes.  I also had radiation.  I have no lymphedema 7 months after finishing rads.

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2011 01:34PM sweetbean wrote: Definitely get a second opinion.  You may  not need chemo, which would be great.  You might consider, however, some alternative therapies if you decide not to do chemo.  Mistletoe is popular in Europe and (I think) Canada as a complementary cancer treatment.  It's not cheap, though, and it isn't covered by insurance.  Low dose neltrexone is very cheap - you just need to find a doctor to prescribe it.  I would recommend reading Life Over Cancer by Dr. Keith Block.  He has lots of great strategies to prevent recurrence.   The oncotype will matter a lot.  If it is high, then do the chemo.  If not, it is really up to you.  Chemo isn't easy, but it is doable.  However, it's a lot to put your body through if it isn't going to be effective.

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2011 10:16PM sweetbean wrote: Hi there!  Thought I would check in - had a BMX with TE's last Thursday - 4/14.  It went really well!  Pain management was problem in the beginning, but we got a handle on it by Friday morning and it hasn't been an issue since.   I am healing well - had a total skin/nipple sparing BMX with inframammary incision, so the incision is under the breast.  Both nipples are a bit bruised, but the doctor said that will clear up easily.  The blood circulation was so good that they were able to expand me a bit during surgery, so I woke up looking somewhat normal. Or, more normal than I thought I would look!  I'm quite happy with the results thus far.  I have a bit of drainage from one of my drain sites, so I am going to see the doctor to make sure everything is cool.  I am sure that it is - I went for a 20 minute walk in Central Park today, so that could have kicked up some extra drainage.  I also have a rash on my stomach - not sure what that is from, but I will show the doctor tomorrow. I have good range of motion - I was able to lift my arm to my shoulder on Friday morning, so I guess that is a good place to start.  It gets a little better each day. The drains are a pain in the  ass, but not painful or anything.  I'm relieved about that.  Very happy that I am through this part!
Posts.Title: April 2011 Masectomy IllinoisNancy Beaglesgirl

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2011 04:25PM sweetbean wrote: OK, so the rash on my stomach is probably a contact dermatitis thing from the bandages and sweat and stuff.  It's not an allergic reaction to the antibiotics.  The bloody dressing was no big deal, either.  Here's one more thing that I'd love to know if anyone else had an experience with - both nipples are a bit bruised and there is a large bruise extending from my nipple to the bottom of my breast as well on one breast.  I saw the breast surgeon today and he did not seem concerned.  Indeed, other stuff I have read indicates that it will heal up just fine.  Anyone else have this experience?   Went on a one-mile walk in the Park today and felt a little tingling under my arm - hope those nerves are regenerating!

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2011 04:33PM sweetbean wrote: Nioxin has methylparaben in it.  Read a very scary study about methylparabens and breast cancer - the methylparaben inhibits Tamoxifen and prevents it from working.  It also makes healthy breast cells more likely to turn cancerous, if I remember correctly.  Very scary stuff.  Not worth it.  I'm using growth stuff by Jason and John Masters.

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2011 03:35PM sweetbean wrote: Seriously.  Someone told me I was lucky to not have to spend money on coloring my hair, because she just spent $200.  I know she was kidding and trying to be nice, but I nearly knocked her into next week.  Strangely, being bald wasn't as bad for me as the growing in phase.  It seems to be taking forever and I'm so frustrated.  I'm 14.5 weeks PFC and still don't have complete coverage on top.  I really thought I would be there by now, but I started Herceptin, which I have heard slows growth.  I also have a theory regarding doing neo-adjuvant chemo and then surgery.  The trauma of surgery is known to cause hair changes and slow hair growth about 8 weeks after surgery.  For women who have surgery first, their body experiences that effect while they are going through chemo.  By the time they are finished with chemo, their body is through that "What-the-hell-just-happened" phase and hair is ready to start growing .  For those of us who have surgery second, our bodies experience that phase right when hair growth should be picking up speed and so it slows down again.  I wonder if any other neo-adjuvant girls have experienced this.... although maybe I am just super impatient. i guess it's hard because I am single and I really want to feel normal and like I could potentially date.  and i just can't date like this...*sigh*

Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2011 03:09PM sweetbean wrote: bdavis, we are the You Can Thrive team.  (You Can Thrive is a non-profit in NYC that provides free and low cost CAM therapies to breast cancer survivors.)  I have been training for months, but the most miles I have walked at once is 16.  So we will see how it goes.  I got new sneakers, so I am working on breaking them in.   It's totally cool that everyone has different philosophies and ways to get through this.  It makes me feel better to completely alter my diet and lifestyle choices, but for some, it would feel like cancer took over everything.  I get that.  But I had a BMX because, as I said to my sister, "I would rather cut off a perfectly healthy part of my body than put Mom & Dad through this again."   So for me, it's not a big stretch to read every label or drink a kale smoothie every day of my life, even if it isn't exactly tasty.   I spend a LOT of time reading studies and information and feel obliged to share what I read with the women on this site, because I want to help everybody.  Knowledge is power.    Now, I just have to figure out how to post a picture....
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2012 12:44PM sweetbean wrote: MargieC, are you still on Herceptin?  Herceptin is DEFINITELY slowing my hair growth down.  Mkw1, my hair grew in like that, too.  It eventually filled in, although it is still a little sparse at the temples.  I've started using Rogaine to speed the process up.  But I think it is the Herceptin, so I am trying to be patient.  I finished chemo Mar 22, 2011, so I am almost 10 months out.  It probably took  me 6 months before I looked somewhat normal.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2012 08:43AM sweetbean wrote: I agree with Alesta  - This is interesting, but no easy answers.  When I was in the hospital for my BMX, I watched a similar situation unfold.  I had been in there for one day, was obviously in a lot of pain.  At around midnight, I got a new roommate.  She was morbidly obese, accompanied by her daughter, and yelling about how much pain she was in.  The doctors came in and tried to take a history, but to no avail.  She would only tell them that her stomach hurt, but couldn't seem to provide any details.  Her daughter was competely fed up with her mother - so frustrated that she wouldn't cooperate AND that she (apparentaly) had the worst eating habits on the planet.  Daughter clearly felt that her mother was bringing this on herself.   Once the doctors and her daughter left, the patient turned on the TV, turned up the volume, and then made a phone call and had a conversation almost in a full shout.  As far as I could tell, she was not hard of hearing - nobody needed to raise their voice for her to hear them.  So the yelling into the phone was kind of unbelievable.  Especially since I was in the next bed and at this point, it was one am.  My mother was sitting with me and she wheeled by me to get to her bed, so there is no way she didn't realize that I was there.  Finally, she got off the phone and proceeded to fall asleep with the TV blaring.  My mother got up and turned it off.   The next morning, more doctors came in to try and figure out what was wrong.  Again, she wouldn't provide any type of information.  I have to say, I've never seen anything like it.   I mean, yes, she was in pain, but she didn't seem that interested in helping the doctors diagnose her so that they could help her.   The doctors got completely frustrated and left.   Now, unless you think I am feeling bad for the doctors, I'm not.  this is their job.  There are going to be difficult patients.  Not everyone will be a cute five year old or an adorable grandmother.  There will people who make choices and live lives that you don't agree with and you really have to treat them all.  I felt like the doctors weren't trying hard enough.  But I also understood why the doctors and her family were frustrated - here is a woman who is clearly using up a lot of different resources (medical, financial, emotional) and literally doing nothing to help herself or change her situation. And yet, I don't know her or her situation, so I am trying not to judge.  Like alesta said, no easy answers.    Anyway,  that was my experience.  Also, sidebar - I got incredibly crappy pain management from that hospital during my stay, so it wasn't like my cheerful, educated, and engaged self got better medical care.

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2012 10:24PM sweetbean wrote: KrystalRose, Casein protein has been definitively linked to cancer - read the China Study or Life Over Cancer.  Whey protein, on other hand, has many anti-cancer properties.  Please consider switching to whey protein.  (The dangers of casein are the reason I gave up dairy - milk protein is made up of 80% casein and 20% whey.) Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2012 11:55PM sweetbean wrote: ProudMom,  I agree with the others - she knows that you are there.  Have you mentioned these boards to her husband?  The people she needs to talk to are other women who know what she is going through.  Honestly, if he's running into you on purpose, I think he's the one who needs to talk.  So you could just talk to him, ask him how he's doing, etc. Giving him some sort of support might help him support her better, you know?  (Of course, you don't want to seem inappropriate, but I know that you won't do that.) I am in a similar situation - several friends have put me in touch with a mutual friend who was diagnosed Stage IV from the get-go.  Our friends all think that we are in the same boat, but I know that isn't true at all.  I got some great advice on how to approach the situation from the women on these boards and and I honestly think I did it right.  I mostly correspond with her through her husband (she's had a rough first few months), but he said that she feels really supported by me.  Anyway, the ladies here are giving you good advice.  And stormynyte, I'm so sorry about what your dad did.  He was probably trying to help, but dear lord.

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 01:52PM - edited Feb 17, 2011 01:54PM by sweetbean I second what Claire said.  I am little more than half way through treatment and I am having a similar experience.  It's not a picnic, but it is doable.  Steroids are a given for most people, I believe.  I haven't gained any weight - in fact, I have lost ten pounds since my diagnosis by really eating super cleanly and exercising.  The doctors are thrilled with my progress - the tumor is shrinking like crazy and my lymph nodes feel "fine," according to my onc. (One was a palpable lump on diagnosis.) I make sure to exercise every day, even the day after treatment.  Treadmill or yoga.  I also drank a ton of water DURING the actual infusion.  It helped to move the chemo through my system and I didn't have as much nausea.  Don't worry, it will still be in there long enough to do its job.  On my third treatment, I didn't drink enough water during infusion and I felt MUCH sicker later.    I do a lot of guided imagery and visualization, too.  That really helps.    Claire, what was your recovery from your lymph node surgery like?  How long before you were exercising etc?  Any tips for preventing lymphedema?

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2011 07:51AM sweetbean wrote: Hi, I just had a BMX and ALND, but my ALND was targeted - the doctor did a procedure known as Reverse Arm Mapping or Axillary Reverse Mapping.  It is a very new procedure - they inject your arm with a dye during surgery just before the ALND.  When they go into take the lymph nodes, the arm lymph nodes turn a different color, so they don't take them.  They just take the lymph nodes that are associated with the breast.  This procedure is supposed to reduce the risk of lymphedema.  I hope so - even with this procedure, they still took 15 breast lymph nodes.  Whew!
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Dissection or not? Randi64 sweetbean

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2012 02:50PM sweetbean wrote: Hi there, I walked at a speed of 3.5 for 45-60 minutes (down from my usual 4.0) all during chemo a few times a week.  I also took yoga classes 4-5 times a week.  It helped keep my energy high and I didn't gain a pound during chemo - actually lost weight.  I also think it was important, especially during Taxol, to keep moving.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2011 04:39PM sweetbean wrote: Here's the thing that always gets me - every time this subject comes up, people tend to lean towards the fact that there are plenty of people who don't drink that got cancer and plenty of people who do drink that didn't get cancer.  They like this comparison because it shows that whether or not you drink has nothing to do with whether or not you got cancer.  I'm not going to argue that point, because I RARELY drank and I still got cancer.  HOWEVER,  we are not in the group that can wonder if we will get cancer if we drink.  We already have cancer (or had it) which means our risk of getting cancer is MUCH higher than the general population.  So we need to be extra vigilant with our choices. There are women who can smoke, drink, and eat sausage until they are 103 and they will never get cancer.  We are not those women.    That being said, did we cause our cancer?  Nope.  Can we influence our prognosis through diet and lifestyle choices?  I firmly believe so.    (I don't believe I am genetically predisposed to cancer - I am the only one with cancer in my family, including my identical twin sister.)
Posts.Title: alcohol and bc risk hdangelbaby CameoBarbie

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2011 07:20PM sweetbean wrote: It might not be leukemia!  We hauled ourselves up to Dana Farber (sidebar - they are AMAZING) and the oncologist looked at her bloodwork and said, "this isn't definitive at all.  I see a few markers that are a little elevated, but they could also be elevated because of your throat infection."  Her WBC had gone back to normal and she had no blasts in her blood (very good news).  She did a bone marrow biopsy and is going to go on IV antibiotics while we wait for the results.  Hoping against hope right now.  Please, keep the prayers coming!

Posts.Content: sweetbean wrote: OK, so I am still anemic - I finished chemo over a year ago.  Just finished Herceptin on May 17, 2012.  Not hugely anemic, but iron deficiency is not good for you.  I don't eat meat and can't eat shellfish.  I eat more green leafy vegetables than you can shake a stick at, plus beans.  There is some tweaking to my diet that I could do, but at this point, I think I probably need  a vitamin.  So I was thinking of a pre-natal vitamin - they have iron and people say it helps with hair growth.  My hair came back the same, but it grew slowly due to the Herceptin - I'd love to give it a boost. Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 01:36PM - edited Apr 21, 2011 01:36PM by sweetbean Is your neuropathy profound?  If it is, then, yes, lots of people stop before then end with Taxol.  If it isn't, definitely finish.  I continued to see my tumor shrink even after my fourth round of Taxol, so it was still working.  Are you taking supplements to prevent neuropathy?  I took 3000 mgs of Acteyl-L-Carnitine, 200mgs of Vit. B6, 100mgs of Vit B1, and 1 scoop of Glutamine (I think it is 2000mgs). With those supplements, I did not experience any neuropathy.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with BC. AIDS for 20+yrs. StayinAlive68 Shachar

Posts.Content: sweetbean wrote: Hi all, My friend was just diagnosed Stage IV - she was diagnosed at Stage III a year ago.  She just finished treatment in mid-September, but was told right before Christmas that it is now in her liver, bones, and under the skin.  She told me that she is starting cis-platinum (I think she means Cisplatin) tomorrow.  I'm really sad for her and was wondering if anyone has any advice about Cisplatin.   She didn't tell me if she was getting that in combo with anything else, like Gemzar. She did ACT last year, which didn't work at all.  The tumor barely shrank.  Then she had a BMX and radiation.  Then she did Tamoxifen, which obviously failed.  I'm guessing that it is now behaving as a TN cancer, since our onc is trying a platinum drug and not a hormonal.  (She isn't super clear on the details and I don't want to pepper her with questions.   She jokingly asked me if I wanted to come sit with her during her infusion tomorrow.  I'd have to rearrange work, but I'm thinking about it.)   Any advice about Cisplatin and its side effects would be greatly appreciated.  She is 32, engaged to be married to a great guy, and has an adorable 5 year-old boy.   Many thanks and much love... Dx 11/18/2010, ILC, 5cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 2, 2/15 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ (FISH) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2012 03:05PM sweetbean wrote: So we went today for the ultrasound and biopsy and....nobody could find the lump.  Not the radiologist or the doctor.  So she goes for an MRI tomorrow to see if it is still there and, if it is, biopsy it.  She got her first MRI waaaaaay too close to her period, so I'm hoping that this little spot is just hormonal changes.  Plus, I saw the MRI films and lump looked totally round.  They said it had "indistinct margins," but it sure didn't look that way to me.  Now, MY lump - those were some indistinct margins!
Posts.Title: My sister has a lump - needs biopsy sweetbean sweetbean

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2011 09:51AM - edited Nov 4, 2011 09:52AM by sweetbean Yes, SoulSista, it does.  The problem with cancer treatments is that they never completely eliminate ALL of the cancer cells.  And the ones that are left over are often resistant to treatment.  So at that point, it is about making the terrain (your body) as hostile to cancer as possible.  So cutting sugar, meat, dairy, all the things that feed cancer, is very helpful.  Beer and liquor are very bad, cancer-wise.  Red wine is the best choice because it has antioxidants, but drink it with food, so it doesn't cause a blood sugar spike.  And probably limit yourself to one drink a night.    Alcohol makes your natural killer cells sluggish, impairs macrophage activity and reduces T cell counts.It also increases your levels of oxidative stress, which impairs your body's inflammatory response.  Result: more inflammation, which has been linked to cancer.   Alcohol also slows down your metabolism, which makes you gain weight.  Also not good for breast cancer.    Our cancer started with ONE cell that went haywire.  So making the terrain as inhospitable to those cells is important.  I know that it sucks.  I miss my old life, too. And while I don't think that we "caused" our cancer,  I have also read enough to know that diet/lifestyle does make a difference.  I also know that there are plenty of health nut/vegans that get cancer.  However, I don't think that  they are in the majority.  I considered myself a health nut before I got diagnosed, but I was still able to make a lot of changes which means my lifestyle wasn't as healthy as I thought it was.   hdangelbaby, I'm sorry that your friend said that.  She is probably scared out of her mind for both of you.  People say the strangest things to reassure themselves that they won't get cancer.   But, if I were you, I'd cut out the alcohol except for special occasions.  Totally up to you, though.
